SEARCH
Package gw.api.web.color

Class GWColor

java.lang.Object
gw.api.web.color.GWColor
public class GWColor extends Object
Helper for expressions that result in dynamic colors. Supports legacy css3 color names and new themeable color types via: CssColorsLevel3, or THEME_TYPE. use GWColor.createFromPCFColorString(String color) to build. Until more complicated situations come into play, the only needed method is getCssClassForWidgetRenderer(), which will return a string of gw-app--gwcolor--`colornameortype` that maps to a class in SCSS files. Overview of UI Color: Some widgets have PCF fields that allow a color to be input. Some allow directly inputting a color value, such as a CSS3 name, or a hex value. Some require an instance of GwColor. GwColor is a java class with a number of helper methods for adding color. Manually adding the color `GwColor.createFromHex(#0000FF)` or `GwColor.createFromCssLevel3Color('blue')` to a PCF field will cause that field to be blue. However, GW Applications have multiple themes. If you plan to support themeing then it is rarely the case that you'd want to directly specify a color. Instead, you would want to specify a concept, and then let the themes translate that concept into a color that makes sense for the context. The simplest way to do specify theme safe colors is to use the GwColor static instances; such as 'GwColor.THEME_NUMBERS_NEGATIVE` or `GwColor.THEME_OUTCOME_POSITIVE`. Using these instances will cause the widget to have a css class that is then manipulated per theme. 'positive' might be a very light green color in the 'dark theme', or a darker green in the 'blue theme'. Typing `GwColor.T` should provide you with an intellisense dropdown of all the options. But you can also see the static references directly in GwColor.java. The GwColor THEME instances are mapped to Sass color values in `platform_colors_themeable_in_pcf.scss`. Further, some widgets expose selecting colors as a higher level abstraction, called widgetStyles: because these widgets need to make use of more than one color, or require colors to interact in specific ways. These PCF fields take a value of `WidgetStyleEnum`--and you can select things like `WidgetStyleError` or `WidgetStyleSuccess` from the intellisense dropdown. Many, if not all, colors visible in the application that are not exposed directly in PCFs (like Button colors, or the color of the left navigation panel, etc) can all be changed and themed directly in Sass files.

    • processColorExpressionResult

      public static Optional<GWColor> processColorExpressionResult(Object nullOrStrOrGWColor)
      Helper method to process the return value of a PCF expression whose intent is to return a "color" value: either the legacy CSS String values, or the new GWColor object.
      Parameters:
      nullOrStrOrGWColor - - null, String, or GWColor
      Returns:
      Optional

    • createFromPCFColorString

      public static Optional<GWColor> createFromPCFColorString(String cssOrThemeColor)
      Required constructor for Legacy implementations where the color expression returns a string and not a GWColor
      Parameters:
      cssOrThemeColor - - a string to be appended to the css class to be added to the widget. If the themeColor corresponds to a CSssColorsLevel3 enum, then the hex value will also be used as the object instances actual Color.
      Returns:

    • getInlineAttrIfNotCssOrThemeType

      public Optional<String> getInlineAttrIfNotCssOrThemeType()
      Used by widget renderers to get the needed inline style attribute value, but only returns a value if the instance has not been given a cssColor or theme type.
      Returns:

    • getCssClassForWidgetRenderer

      public Optional<String> getCssClassForWidgetRenderer(String style)
      Primary public method for widget renderers. If this returns empty, then getInlineAttrIfNotCssOrThemeType will return a value.
      Parameters:
      style - - the css style attribute this color will be used for. ie gw-app--gwcolor--background-color--red
      Returns:

    • getRGBACss

      public String getRGBACss()
      returns valid inline style value in the form of rgba(255,255,255,.5)

    • getHexCss

      public String getHexCss()
      returns a valid hex string, ie #FFFFFF.
